questions.text: Among the given options, murmur given in the image is associated with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mitral Regurgitation

 

The image provided indicates a murmur occurring between S1 and S2, which is described as a pan-systolic murmur. This type of murmur spans the entirety of systole.

 

Mitral Regurgitation produces a pan-systolic murmur due to the backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium throughout systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic Regurgitation: Characterized by an early diastolic murmur due to backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.

 

Option C. Mitral Stenosis: Characterized by a mid-diastolic murmur due to obstructed blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Option D. Aortic Stenosis: Characterized by an ejection systolic murmur due to turbulent blood flow across a narrowed aortic valve during systole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral regurgitation is associated with a pan-systolic murmur, which is present throughout the systole and heard between the S1 and S2 heart sounds.

choices.text: Loud S1 is a common finding
Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of chest pain and upper respiratory tract infection, seven days ago, presents with shortness of breath. She has BP of 100/60 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 110/min. Chest x-ray reviews an enlarged heart, which appears like a water bottle. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loud S1 is a common finding

 

The patient is likely suffering from pericardial effusion, possibly progressing to cardiac tamponade, secondary to a recent viral infection. This is suggested by the history of an upper respiratory tract infection, the physical findings, and the characteristic "water bottle" appearance of the heart on the chest x-ray.

 

The incorrect statement is Loud S1 is a common finding. In fact, one of the hallmarks of cardiac tamponade is muffled or distant heart sounds due to the insulating effect of the pericardial fluid, as described in Beck's triad, which includes hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus Paradoxus is usually seen: This is true. Pulsus paradoxus is a significant drop in blood pressure during inspiration, common in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option B. Pericardiocentesis may be required: This is true. Pericardiocentesis is often necessary to remove the excess fluid and relieve pressure on the heart, especially if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

 

Option D. Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse: This is true. In cardiac tamponade, the pressure from the pericardial fluid prevents the right atrium and right ventricle from expanding during diastole, leading to their collapse. Echocardiography will reveal this diastolic collapse, confirming cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, muffled heart sounds are a key finding, not a loud S1.

questions.text: Below is a radioactive scan for thyroid pathology. which of the following is the most probable diagnosis: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypersecreting Adenoma

 

Image findings are suggestive of hypersecreting adenoma.

 

  1. Increased uptake in the right lobe at the thyroid
  2. Suppressed uptake in left lobe of thyroid

 

These findings are highly suggestive of a hypersecreting adenoma. This condition occurs when a benign tumor in the thyroid gland produces thyroid hormone independently of the normal regulatory mechanisms, leading to an overactive area (hot spot) in one part of the thyroid, with suppression of activity in the rest of the gland due to negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: Incorrect as this type of cancer typically presents with a "cold nodule," which shows reduced or no uptake on a radioactive scan. The scan shows no areas of reduced uptake indicative of a cold nodule.

 

Option C. Grave’s disease: Incorrect because Grave's disease generally causes a diffuse increase in uptake across the entire thyroid gland due to widespread stimulation of thyroid tissue. The scan does not show diffuse uptake, which rules out Grave's disease.

 

Option D. Lateral aberrant thyroid: Incorrect as this condition involves ectopic thyroid tissue that might appear as functioning thyroid tissue outside the normal location. The scan does not indicate any ectopic thyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypersecreting adenoma in the thyroid is characterized by increased radioactive uptake in one area of the thyroid with suppression in other areas, reflecting independent hormone production from the adenoma.

questions.text: A patient with retro-positive status was started on 2nd line highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Viral load

 

Viral load measurement is the primary method used to monitor the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in patients with HIV. According to WHO and NACO guidelines, the monitoring of viral load is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of the treatment. Initially, viral load is monitored every six months until the regimen is stabilized. After that, it is monitored annually.

 

The goal of ART is to achieve an undetectable viral load, defined as less than 50 copies per mL. If the viral load is less than 50 copies, it indicates effective suppression of the virus, and the patient can continue with the same ART regimen with yearly monitoring.

 

If the viral load exceeds 1000 copies, it suggests treatment failure, necessitating a change in the ART regimen.

 

For viral loads between 50 and 1000 copies, the issue is often due to poor adherence to therapy, and it is recommended to ensure adherence and frequently monitor viral load every three months until suppression is achieved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD4+ T cell count: Previously, CD4+ T cell count was commonly used to monitor HIV treatment. However, current guidelines prioritize viral load over CD4 count for monitoring treatment efficacy. While CD4 count is still important for assessing the immune system's health, it is not the primary marker for treatment efficacy.

 

Option C. p24 antigen: The p24 antigen is a protein associated with HIV. It is used for early detection of HIV infection but is not suitable for monitoring long-term treatment efficacy. p24 levels do not provide reliable information on viral suppression or ART effectiveness.

 

Option D. Viral serotype: Viral serotyping involves identifying different strains of HIV but does not provide information on treatment efficacy. It is more relevant in epidemiological studies and vaccine development rather than in monitoring ongoing therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral load measurement is the most important and recommended method for monitoring the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in HIV patients. The goal is to achieve an undetectable viral load (<50 copies/mL).

questions.text:
Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Pulmonary area

2.Erb’s area

3.Mitral area
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 → 2 → 3

 

The heart sounds are heard in the following order from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall:

 

Pulmonary area: 2nd intercostal space near the sternum →Erb’s area (2nd aortic area): 3rd intercostal space near the sternum → Mitral area: 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line (away from sternum).


Educational Objective:

 

The correct order from superior to inferior for heart sounds on the left side chest wall is pulmonary area, Erb’s area, and mitral area.

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is due to which of the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asthenospermia

 

Asthenospermia (Immotile sperm [Greek sthenos = strength]

 

Kartagener result from loss of function of axonemal dynein that impairs sperm motility. Respiratory Ciliary dysmotility leads to bronchiectasis and recurrent infections. Association of situs inversus is noted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oligospermia: Incorrect because while sperm count can be affected in some genetic or hormonal disorders, in Kartagener's syndrome, the sperm count is typically normal; the issue lies in their motility.

 

Option C. Epididymis obstruction: Incorrect as this is not a feature of Kartagener’s syndrome. While structural anomalies in the reproductive tract can lead to such issues, Kartagener’s syndrome specifically affects the motility of sperm due to ciliary dysfunction.

 

Option D. Undescended testes: Incorrect as undescended testes are not associated with Kartagener’s syndrome, which primarily affects ciliary function and not the anatomical position of the testes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is primarily due to asthenospermia, which is caused by the immobility of sperm. This immotility results from the genetic defect affecting the dynein arm of sperm flagella, similar to the defect affecting cilia in the respiratory tract, leading to the classic symptoms of the syndrome.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Bronchiectasis/Chapter 290

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

1. Atorvastatin 

2. Aspirin 

3. Clopidogrel 

4. Low molecular weight heparin 

5. Alteplase
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:  

 

In the management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), several medications are routinely used to reduce the risk of further ischemic events and manage the condition effectively:

 

  1. Atorvastatin: High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques.
  2. Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage.
  3. Clopidogrel: Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events.
  4. Low molecular weight heparin: Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.

 

Other Option:

 

5. Alteplase: This thrombolytic agent is used in the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available. It is not indicated for NSTEMI due to the lack of ST elevation and the associated risks of bleeding without significant benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For NSTEMI management, the treatment includes Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and Low molecular weight heparin. Thrombolytic agents like Alteplase are reserved for STEMI with specific indications.

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in medicine ward with fever. What could be the possible diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Image shows typical biphasic illness with initial leptospiremic phase followed by immune phase.

 

Other illness that shows biphasic pattern include measles, Tick borne encephalitis virus, rarely Zika virus.

 

Modified Faine Criteria is used for diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monophasic illness with predominant CNS and multisystem involvement.

 

Option C. Undulant fever presenting with PUO, muscle pain, thoracic backpain

 

Option D. Enteric fever causes step ladder pattern of fever.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a biphasic fever pattern, especially when supported by epidemiologic data pointing to possible exposure to contaminated water or animals. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as Weil's disease, which can lead to severe renal and hepatic issues.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Leptospirosis/Chap 184

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with a complaint of severe headaches. Physical examination reveals a slightly elevated blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg, and the neurological exam shows no focal deficits, but the patient appears visibly distressed and in pain. Which of the following types of headaches requires further evaluation?

 

  1. Headache lasting more than a few hours without relief
  2. Sudden onset severe headache described as the "worst headache of life"
  3. New-onset headache that is progressively worsening
  4. Headache associated with visual symptoms, such as blurred vision
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Option 2: Sudden onset severe headache described as the "worst headache of life"
This description is a classic red flag for a subarachnoid hemorrhage, particularly when the headache occurs suddenly and with severe intensity. Such a presentation requires immediate evaluation with neuroimaging, typically a CT scan, to rule out a potentially life-threatening condition.

 

Option 3: New-onset headache that is progressively worsening
A new, progressively worsening headache, particularly in a patient without a prior history of similar headaches, suggests a serious underlying condition such as a brain tumor, increased intracranial pressure, or another significant pathology. This warrants further evaluation with neuroimaging to determine the cause.

 

Option 4: Headache associated with visual symptoms, such as blurred vision
Headaches with associated visual symptoms raise concern for conditions like increased intracranial pressure, optic neuritis, or other neurological disorders. Blurred vision with headache necessitates prompt evaluation to exclude serious conditions.

 

Other Option:

 

Option 1: Headache lasting more than a few hours without relief
While prolonged headaches can be distressing, they often occur in benign conditions such as migraines or tension-type headaches. The duration alone does not necessitate urgent evaluation unless it is accompanied by other red flag symptoms, such as neurological changes or sudden onset.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Headaches that present as the worst headache of one’s life, are new and progressively worsening, or are associated with visual disturbances require urgent medical evaluation. These red flags suggest potential serious conditions like subarachnoid hemorrhage, brain tumors, or increased intracranial pressure, necessitating prompt investigation and management to prevent complications.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oral Candidiasis

 

Oral candidiasis, while commonly associated with HIV infection, is not itself an AIDS-defining illness. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) list of AIDS-defining illnesses includes more severe manifestations such as candidiasis of the esophagus, trachea, bronchi, or lungs, but not oral candidiasis. This fungal infection is often seen in patients with HIV as a marker of immune suppression but does not qualify as an indicator of AIDS on its own.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalopathy attributed to HIV: This is an AIDS-defining condition, as it represents a direct effect of HIV on the brain resulting in cognitive impairment and motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Invasive cervical cancer: This is considered an AIDS-defining illness due to the high risk and prevalence of this cancer in individuals with advanced HIV, reflecting a significant degree of immunosuppression.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis of any site: Tuberculosis, whether pulmonary or extrapulmonary, is an AIDS-defining illness due to its severity and frequency in the context of HIV-induced immune suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Infectious Disease/Chap 202

questions.text:
A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presented with withdrawal symptoms. His liver function tests showed:

 

AST 140 IU/L,

 

ALT 110 IU/L, and

 

GGT 500 IU/L.

 

Which of the following benzodiazepines can be safely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lorazepam

 

The patient's liver function tests indicate elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT, and GGT), suggesting potential alcoholic hepatitis or liver impairment. In such cases, choosing the appropriate benzodiazepine is crucial due to the liver's role in drug metabolism.

 

Lorazepam is a preferred benzodiazepine in patients with liver impairment for the following reasons:

 

  1. Short-acting: Lorazepam is a short-acting benzodiazepine, which means it has a shorter half-life and less risk of accumulation in the body compared to long-acting benzodiazepines.
  2. Minimal liver metabolism: Lorazepam undergoes minimal hepatic metabolism, which makes it safer for patients with impaired liver function. This reduces the risk of adverse effects and toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diazepam: Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine. It undergoes extensive hepatic metabolism, leading to active metabolites that can accumulate, especially in patients with liver dysfunction. This increases the risk of prolonged sedation and toxicity.

 

Option B. Alprazolam: Alprazolam, although shorter-acting than diazepam, still undergoes significant liver metabolism. It is not as safe as lorazepam in patients with compromised liver function.

 

Option C. Clonazepam: Clonazepam is also a long-acting benzodiazepine with extensive hepatic metabolism. Like diazepam, its use in patients with liver impairment can lead to accumulation and increased risk of side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with liver impairment, such as those with alcoholic hepatitis, lorazepam is the preferred benzodiazepine due to its short-acting nature and minimal hepatic metabolism.

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman is not responsive to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and family history of bladder cancer. She does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is a suitable oral medication for a diabetic patient not responding to metformin, especially when she has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer, and prefers to avoid injectable medications. Canagliflozin works by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2), which helps the kidneys excrete glucose through urine, thus lowering blood glucose levels

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: Not ideal as it has been associated with a risk of acute pancreatitis, which poses a significant risk given her medical history.

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Should be avoided due to its potential link with bladder cancer, especially considering her family history.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Although effective in managing diabetes, it is not suitable as it is an injectable medication and the patient prefers to avoid injections. Moreover, it also carries a risk of pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In choosing diabetes medications for patients with specific health concerns, it's crucial to consider both the efficacy and the side-effect profile of the drug, as well as patient preferences for administration methods to ensure compliance and safety. Canagliflozin is an appropriate choice for this patient due to its oral administration and lower risk concerning her medical history.

questions.text: A patient presented with violent, flinging movements. Where is the lesion causing the hemiballismus seen? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subthalamic nucleus

 

Hemiballismus is characterized by involuntary, violent, flinging movements, typically on one side of the body. This condition is most commonly associated with a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. The subthalamic nucleus plays a crucial role in regulating movements, and damage to this area can lead to the excessive, uncontrolled movements seen in hemiballismus. This differentiates it from lesions in other parts of the basal ganglia, which are associated with different movement disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Putamen: Lesions in the putamen are more commonly associated with chorea, which involves rapid, involuntary, and irregular movements, rather than the violent flinging movements of hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Caudate nucleus: Similar to the putamen, lesions in the caudate nucleus typically result in chorea. The caudate nucleus is part of the striatum, and its dysfunction does not usually present with the violent movements characteristic of hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Globus pallidus: Lesions in the globus pallidus often result in athetosis, which involves slow, writhing movements. This is different from the abrupt and forceful movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemiballismus, characterized by violent, flinging movements, is most commonly caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

questions.text: A 53-year-old gentleman presents with chest pain which is happening at rest. Pain is persistent for 3-5 minutes and he is having recurrent pain over the last 48 hours and he used 3 puffs of GTN to relieve his pain. His current medications include GTN PRN, Atorvastatin 20mg HS, Metoprolol 50mg BID, and Aspirin 75mg OD. His troponin was negative and ECG showed LVH with flattening of the ST segment. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Start enoxaparin 1mg/kg s.c BD

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of unstable angina, given the recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes (left ventricular hypertrophy with ST segment flattening). Despite the negative troponin, which rules out myocardial infarction, the clinical scenario points to a high risk of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

 

For high-risk ACS, especially in a patient already on medications for coronary artery disease (CAD) like aspirin, atorvastatin, and metoprolol, initiating anticoagulation therapy is crucial to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction. Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is recommended at a therapeutic dose of 1 mg/kg subcutaneously twice a day to achieve effective anticoagulation in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Add long-acting nitrate: While long-acting nitrates can help with angina symptoms, they are not the primary treatment for acute management in this scenario. The priority is to stabilize the patient and prevent further thrombotic events.

 

Option B. Increase metoprolol dose to 100mg BID: Increasing the dose of metoprolol may help with angina control, but it does not address the underlying risk of thrombus formation and is not the immediate next step in managing high-risk unstable angina.

 

Option C. Add clopidogrel 75mg OD: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that is beneficial in ACS, but in this acute setting, starting anticoagulation with enoxaparin takes precedence to prevent thrombus formation. Clopidogrel can be added as part of dual antiplatelet therapy later on.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with high-risk unstable angina, especially those with recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes, initiating therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin is a critical step in the acute management to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction.

choices.text: Focal seizures: Lamotrigine, Carbamazepine, Phenytoin, Valproate
Absence seizure: Carbamazepine Ethosuximide, Valproate
Myoclonic seizures: Valproate, Lamotrigine, Clonazepam
Generalized tonic clonic seizures: Valproate, Lamotrigine, Topiramate, Phenytoin, Carbamazepine

questions.text: Which of the following pairings of seizure type and anti-epileptic drug (AED) is incorrect? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Absence Seizures: Carbamazepine, Ethosuximide, Valproate

 

Explanation:

 

The incorrect pairing is Absence Seizures: Carbamazepine, Ethosuximide, Valproate. Carbamazepine is not used in the treatment of absence seizures; in fact, it can exacerbate them. Ethosuximide and Valproate are the appropriate first-line treatment options for absence seizures.

 

Selection of Anti-Epileptic Drugs

 

 

Alternatives

 

 

Drug of Choice for Various Types of Seizures

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal Seizures: Lamotrigine, Carbamazepine, Phenytoin, Valproate: This is a correct pairing, as all these drugs are used in the treatment of focal seizures.

 

Option C. Myoclonic Seizures: Valproate, Lamotrigine, Clonazepam: This is also a correct pairing, as these drugs are used to manage myoclonic seizures.

 

Option D. Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures: Valproate, Lamotrigine, Topiramate, Phenytoin, Carbamazepine: This pairing is accurate as well, with all listed drugs being used to treat generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbamazepine is contraindicated in absence seizures and can worsen them. Ethosuximide and Valproate are the preferred first-line treatments for absence seizures.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fixed central airway obstruction


The flow-volume loop shows flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is characteristic of a fixed central airway obstruction. This pattern suggests an obstruction that affects airflow both during inhalation and exhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fixed distal airway obstruction would not typically affect both phases of the loop.

 

Option C. Variable intrathoracic obstruction affects the expiratory phase more.

 

Option D. Variable extrathoracic obstruction affects the inspiratory phase more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs in a flow-volume loop indicates a fixed central airway obstruction.

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orthostatic hypotension.

 

Lewy body dementia (LBD), also known as dementia with Lewy bodies, is characterized by specific core clinical features. Orthostatic hypotension, while commonly observed in LBD due to autonomic dysfunction, is not classified as a core clinical feature but rather as a supportive feature for diagnosis.

 

Central feature: Dementia (Essential for the diagnosis of DLB).

 

Core Clinical criteria include the following:

 

  1. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  2. Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  3. Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD).
  4. Spontaneous cardinal features of parkinsonism.

 

Supportive Features of LBD:

 

  • Autonomic Dysfunction: Including orthostatic hypotension.
  • Severe Sensitivity to Antipsychotic Drugs: Patients may experience severe motor and neuroleptic sensitivity.
  • Other Hallucinations and Neurological Signs: Can include auditory hallucinations or transient, unexplained loss of consciousness.

 

Onset of dementia preceding or within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism differentiates Lewy Body dementia from Parkinson's disease with dementia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluctuating cognition: Fluctuating cognition is one of the hallmark symptoms of LBD, characterized by significant variations in attention and alertness. This fluctuation is more pronounced than what is typically seen in other forms of dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, and can vary from hour to hour or day to day.

 

Option B. REM sleep behavior disorder: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a core feature of LBD, where patients physically act out their dreams, often vividly. This disorder is a result of the loss of normal muscle atonia that should occur during REM sleep, leading to potentially violent movements and vocalizations during sleep.

 

Option C. Recurrent visual hallucinations: Visual hallucinations in LBD are typically well-formed and detailed, often involving people or animals. These hallucinations are a core feature and differ from the more nebulous or less structured hallucinations seen in other disorders. They are thought to be due to the underlying Lewy body pathology affecting cortical brain areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orthostatic hypotension is a supportive, not core, criterion for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology, DLB Chapter 434 /12305.

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) oxygen gradient typically points to specific causes where the alveolar oxygen (PAO2) and arterial oxygen (PaO2) levels remain proportionate. In this scenario, the primary causes are hypoventilation and situations involving low inspired oxygen tension (low FiO2).

 

Hypoventilation: This condition leads to hypoxemia due to inadequate ventilation. When ventilation is insufficient, the amount of oxygen entering the alveoli drops, leading to a corresponding decrease in the amount of oxygen diffusing into the blood, resulting in hypoxemia. However, because the underlying issue is with ventilation and not with oxygen diffusion or blood flow, the A-a gradient remains normal.

 

Low FiO2 or Low Barometric Pressure: This can occur in scenarios such as high altitude where the barometric pressure is low, leading to reduced oxygen availability in the air. However, these situations were not explicitly listed among the answer choices.

 

According to the reference paragraph, other conditions like ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, diffusion limitation, and alveolar membrane damage, cause an increased A-a gradient due to impaired oxygen transfer across the alveolar membrane or mismatched ventilation and perfusion in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right to left shunt: This condition causes hypoxemia due to blood bypassing the lungs and not getting oxygenated. It leads to an increased A-a gradient because the oxygen content of the arterial blood is significantly lower compared to the alveolar oxygen level.

 

Option B. Ventilation/Perfusion mismatch: This condition results from areas of the lung receiving oxygen but not perfused with blood or areas perfused with blood but not receiving oxygen. It causes an increased A-a gradient due to ineffective oxygen transfer to the blood.

 

Option D. Alveolar membrane damage: This results in impaired oxygen diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to an increased A-a gradient as oxygen transfer from alveoli to blood is hindered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoventilation is a primary cause of hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

Inhalational of anthrax spores (<5 microns) are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages, carried to local mediastinal lymph nodes releasing toxins causing hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

It is category A bioterrorism agent along with plague, botulism

 

Treatment recommended with IV antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin+Clindamycin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical pneumonia occurs in Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Legionella pneumonia causing interstitial infiltrates

 

Option B. Lung abscess is seen as complication of infection with anaerobes, complication of pneumonia, atypical organisms like burkholderia, Infective endocarditis with septic embolism

 

Option D. Bronchopneumonia occurs due to pneumococcus, H.influenza etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemorrhagic mediastinitis is the hallmark presentation of inhalational anthrax, indicating a severe systemic infection that requires immediate medical attention and aggressive antibiotic therapy. Awareness of this presentation is crucial, particularly in contexts involving potential exposure to anthrax spores, such as bioterrorism.

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Troponin – T

 

Troponin-T is the most sensitive and specific biomarker available for diagnosing myocardial infarction (MI) within the early hours of symptom onset. It begins to rise within 3-4 hours of myocardial damage, peaks at around 12-48 hours, and remains elevated for up to 7-10 days, making it highly useful for early diagnosis and detection of recent heart damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LDH: it is a less specific enzyme that may be elevated in many types of tissue damage and is not ideal for early diagnosis of MI.

 

Option C. CKMB: it rises within 4-8 hours of myocardial injury, making it less useful than Troponin-T in the very early stages post-symptom onset.

 

Option D. BNP: it is primarily used to assess heart failure and is not a primary marker for acute myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Rise by >20%of troponin is used for diagnosis of Reinfarction

 

Newer biomarkers: HFABP, miRNA1,21,33

 

Reference - (Cardiology/Biomarkers, MI)

questions.text: What is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dL, prothrombin time 5 seconds (INR = 2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Class B

 

To determine the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score, each of the five clinical measures is scored with points from 1 to 3 based on specific criteria:

 

  1. Bilirubin:
    • <2 mg/dL = 1 point
    • 2-3 mg/dL = 2 points (Patient has 2.5 mg/dL)
    • 3 mg/dL = 3 points
  2. Albumin:
    • 3.5 g/dL = 1 point
    • 2.8-3.5 g/dL = 2 points
    • <2.8 g/dL = 3 points (Patient has 3 g/dL, scoring 2 points)
  3. INR:
    • 1-1.7 = 1 point
    • 1.8-2.3 = 2 points (Patient has INR = 2)
    • 2.3 = 3 points
  4. Ascites:
    • None = 1 point
    • Controlled = 2 points (Patient has mild ascites, scoring 2 points)
    • Refractory = 3 points
  5. Encephalopathy:
    • None = 1 point (Patient has none)
    • Grade 1-2 = 2 points
    • Grade 3-4 = 3 points

 

Scoring Calculation:

 

  • Bilirubin = 2 points
  • Albumin = 2 points
  • INR = 2 points
  • Ascites = 2 points
  • Encephalopathy = 1 point
    Total = 9 points

The patient scores 9 points, placing them in Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class B.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system

 

 

Inference:

 

  • CTP A: 5-6
  • CTP B: 7-9
  • CTP C: 10-15

 

Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chapter 344

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  • HBsAg - NR,
  • Anti HBs - NR,
  • Anti HBc IgM - NR,
  • Anti HBc total - positive,
  • HBeAg - NR,
  • Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's serological markers indicate the following:

 

  • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.

 

  • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.

 

  • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.

 

  • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.

 

  • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.

 

Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.

 

Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by the presence of specific tumors and physical features. This syndrome is often referred to as "Triple M syndrome" because it commonly presents with three key features: mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid body habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. In addition, pheochromocytomas may also occur.

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer originating from the parafollicular cells (C cells) that produce calcitonin. MTC is a hallmark of MEN 2B, making it one of the primary diagnostic criteria for the syndrome.

 

The condition is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, specifically the codon 918 mutation on chromosome 10, which leads to the development of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Café au lait spot: Café au lait spots are not characteristic of MEN 2B syndrome. These pigmented skin lesions are more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and, in some cases, tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C. Parathyroid adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are typically seen in patients with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, not in MEN 2B. These adenomas cause hyperparathyroidism, which is not a feature of MEN 2B.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve gliomas are primarily associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are not a feature of MEN 2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most significant feature of MEN 2B syndrome is the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, alongside mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid body habitus, often linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene

questions.text: A patient with glaucoma presents with a bulging cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Staphyloma

 

High intraocular pressure leads to the thinning of the ocular tissue, thereby resulting in a staphyloma.

 

Staphyloma: It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

 

 

Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma.

 

Types of Staphylomas     -

 

 

Note:

 

The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.

 

The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoconus: This condition involves a progressive thinning and coning of the cornea, leading to visual distortion, but it is not typically associated with glaucoma.

 

Option B. Keratomalacia: A severe form of vitamin A deficiency leading to corneal softening. The association between keratomalacia and glaucoma is not typical, as keratomalacia results primarily from nutritional deficiencies.

 

Option D. Granular dystrophy: A type of corneal dystrophy characterized by the accumulation of granular deposits in the cornea. It is a genetically inherited condition, unrelated to the thinning caused by glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphyloma, particularly anterior and ciliary types, can develop due to high intraocular pressure in glaucoma, leading to the protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weakened cornea or sclera.

choices.text: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA)

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of dizziness, difficulty swallowing, and slurred speech. He reports numbness on the right side of his face and left side of his body, along with blurred vision and a hoarse voice. On examination, he has right-sided Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis), right-sided facial numbness, dysphagia, hoarseness, and diminished gag reflex. His left arm and leg have impaired pain and temperature sensation. Which of the following arteries is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient’s symptoms are consistent with lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome), commonly due to thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). This condition involves multiple structures on the side of the lesion, including the vestibular nuclei (leading to vertigo and nausea), descending sympathetic tract (resulting in Horner’s syndrome), trigeminal nerve nucleus (causing facial numbness), and cranial nerves IX and X (causing dysphagia and hoarseness). Additionally, contralateral spinothalamic tract involvement results in impaired pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basilar artery
A basilar artery stroke often affects the pons and midbrain, leading to severe symptoms such as locked-in syndrome, cranial nerve abnormalities, and quadriplegia, which do not match this patient’s presentation.

 

Option B. Vertebral artery
Vertebral artery strokes can cause a wide variety of brainstem and cerebellar symptoms, but they often present with more diffuse findings compared to PICA strokes. They can sometimes contribute to PICA infarction, but specific involvement of lateral medullary structures like those described here is most characteristic of isolated PICA occlusion.

 

Option D. Middle cerebral artery (MCA)
MCA strokes typically involve the cerebral cortex, presenting with contralateral motor and sensory deficits, aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved), and neglect (if the non-dominant hemisphere is affected). They do not cause the brainstem symptoms described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) results from thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) and presents with a distinctive pattern of cranial nerve deficits, ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. Understanding the unique symptomatology of brainstem stroke syndromes aids in prompt recognition and management.

choices.text: Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, high UE3
Low MSAFP, high hCG, high UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, low UE3

questions.text: A pregnant woman has a fetus with Down's syndrome. Triple test done at 15-16 weeks will have? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3

 

Explanation:

 

The triple and quadruple test is done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triple test results for Down's syndrome typically show low MSAFP, high hCG, and low uE3.

 

Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The most appropriate expansion of Apgar is: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, respiration

 

  • The expansion of Apgar is appearance, pulse, grimace, activity and respiration.

 

 

 

The APGAR score is a quick assessment of a newborn's overall health and well-being immediately after birth. The score is based on a five-point scale that evaluates the newborn's appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration. Each category is scored from 0-2, and the total score ranges from 0-10. A score of 7 or above is considered normal, while a score of 4-6 indicates that the newborn may require some medical attention, and a score of 3 or below indicates that the newborn requires immediate medical attention. The APGAR score is typically assessed at 1 and 5 minutes after birth and may be repeated if necessary.Top of FormBottom of Form

 

Educational Objective:


The Apgar score assesses a newborn's health based on five criteria: Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, and Respiration.

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intussusception

 

Intussusception is a condition where a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment, with the apex of the intussusceptum being more prone to ischemia which leads to gangrene. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. It is commonly seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with very minimal risk of intussusception. An area of enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch acts as a lead point for intussusception.

 

The clinical scenario of pain abdomen with a palpable mass in the right lumbar region along with the barium enema showing claw sign is suggestive of intussusception. Some lead points in children are Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts. Patients usually present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, vomiting, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the target sign bull's eye sign and pseudokidney sign. Management of intussusception includes prompt referral to a pediatric surgeon for reduction by air or contrast enema or surgical intervention if there is a failure of non-operative reduction or clinical instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus, specifically sigmoid volvulus, shows a characteristic "coffee bean" sign on imaging. It involves the twisting of the intestine around itself, which can lead to obstruction and ischemia but presents differently on imaging.

 

Option C. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on imaging, which results from the dilatation of the stomach and proximal duodenum. This condition leads to bilious vomiting and is evident soon after birth.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: General intestinal obstruction shows multiple air-fluid levels on imaging, which is different from the claw sign seen in intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable mass, and red currant jelly stools, and is confirmed by imaging showing the claw sign.

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents in OPD with complaints of cyclical pain in abdomen.  On examination, a suprapubic bulge can be seen in the pelvic area. PR examination reveals a swelling in the anterior aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

The given case scenario points to a diagnosis of cryptomenorrhea, due to an imperforate hymen.

 

Cryptomenorrhea is a condition in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract resulting in either hematometra (blood collection within the uterus) or hematocolpos (blood collection within vagina). In the long term, it may result in endometriosis, urinary retention and infertility.

 

IMPERFORATE HYMEN

 

  • Presents as cryptomenorrhea
  • H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea
  • Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen
  • On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision.

 

 

In Imperforate hymen, swelling is seen all along the length of the vagina on PR examination as there is hematocolpos (blood in the vagina)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse vaginal septum: Transverse vaginal septum is a Müllerian anomaly. On examination, blind vagina is found. No tense blue hymen and cough impulse will be absent. Diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI

 

Option B. Vaginal atresia: If vaginal introitus is not seen, then it’s vaginal atresia

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: Cervical agenesis will show absence of a cervix is on examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imperforate hymen presents with cryptomenorrhea, characterized by cyclical abdominal pain and hematocolpos due to obstruction of menstrual flow, with a suprapubic bulge and anterior swelling palpable on PR examination.

questions.text: In the 18th century, the East India Company engaged in the illicit trade of a specific substance with China, which played a significant role in the historical trade dynamics. What was the substance that the company smuggled into China during this time? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Opium

 

Explanation:

 

  • In 18th & 19th centuaries, EIC (East India Company) used to purchase Tea against Silver. 
  • By opium export, EIC were able to save their Silver and purchased tea against Opium.
  • Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cannabis: Marijuana, a psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Option D. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China .

choices.text: X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets
Vitamin D dependent rickets type I
Vitamin D dependent rickets type II

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with developmental delay, recurrent chest infections and worsening bony pain. His serum PTH was normal. Calcium was normal and phosphate was low. There is no response to Vitamin D. The probable diagnosis is:(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets

 

  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder characterized by low phosphate levels in the blood due to impaired phosphate reabsorption by the kidneys. This condition can lead to bone deformities, bony pain, and growth delays. Normal PTH levels are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Nutritional rickets:

  • Nutritional rickets is typically caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. In this case, the boy has normal serum PTH, which suggests that his body is not compensating for a Vitamin D deficiency. Additionally, his phosphate levels are low despite Vitamin D supplementation, which is not characteristic of nutritional rickets.

 

Option C: Vitamin D dependent rickets type I:

  • This condition is caused by a genetic mutation that impairs the conversion of Vitamin D to its active form. It usually presents with low calcium levels and elevated PTH, which is not in line with the boy's normal PTH levels.

 

Option D: Vitamin D dependent rickets type II:

  • Vitamin D dependent rickets type II is another genetic disorder that affects the body's response to Vitamin D. It can lead to low calcium levels and elevated PTH, which do not match the boy's normal PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder that results in low phosphate levels and can present with bony pain, developmental delay, and recurrent infections. It is distinct from other forms of rickets due to its genetic basis and the characteristic low phosphate levels in the absence of Vitamin D response.

 

Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562285/

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

Amiodarone is a class III anti arrhythmic drug. One of the adverse effects of amiodarone that is seen with long term therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive. Therefore, it is contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease.

 

The other adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism (Amiodarone is 40% iodine by weight), blue grey skin pigmentation, corneal deposits, constipation and bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sotalol: Sotalol is also a class III antiarrhythmic agent but does not have the same risk of pulmonary toxicity as amiodarone. It is generally considered safer for patients with interstitial lung disease.

 

Option C. Quinidine: Quinidine is a class I antiarrhythmic drug that is not associated with pulmonary toxicity. It has other potential side effects but is not contraindicated in interstitial lung disease.

 

Option D. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (lidocaine) is a class Ib antiarrhythmic agent primarily used for ventricular arrhythmias. It does not have pulmonary toxicity and is not contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease due to its potential to cause pulmonary fibrosis, a serious and potentially irreversible adverse effect. It is essential to consider this risk when prescribing antiarrhythmic therapy to patients with pre-existing lung conditions.

choices.text: Replace amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide with losartan and a different diuretic, and add polyethylene glycol for constipation.
Discontinue sertraline and olanzapine, start a new antidepressant and antipsychotic, and add polyethylene glycol.
Continue current medications and add senna for constipation relief.
Stop all medications and initiate corticosteroid therapy.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with a history of high blood pressure and recent mood fluctuations presents with persistent difficulty passing stool. His blood pressure is elevated while sitting but drops significantly when lying down. He is currently taking amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, sertraline, olanzapine, and psyllium husk. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Replace amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide with losartan and a different diuretic, and add polyethylene glycol for constipation.

 

Explanation:

 

The patient is experiencing orthostatic hypotension, indicated by the significant drop in blood pressure when changing from sitting to lying down. This could be a side effect of his antihypertensive medications (amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide). Additionally, constipation could be exacerbated by these medications or the antipsychotic olanzapine.

The best approach is to address both issues simultaneously. Switching to an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) like losartan can help manage hypertension while minimizing the risk of orthostatic hypotension. Changing to a different diuretic can further mitigate the risk of low blood pressure upon standing. Adding polyethylene glycol, an osmotic laxative, can effectively relieve constipation without interacting with other medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Changing psychotropic medications might not be the primary concern, as the orthostatic hypotension and constipation may be primarily medication-related.

 

Option C: Adding senna without addressing the medications causing orthostatic hypotension might not be the most effective approach.

 

Option D: Stopping all medications abruptly and starting steroids is not recommended as it can lead to withdrawal symptoms and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with orthostatic hypotension and constipation, consider adjusting medications that may contribute to these issues. Look for alternative antihypertensives and constipation relief options that have a lower risk of side effects and drug interactions

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.

 

The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 4

 

  • The given image shows a pressure sore with extensive tissue destruction, including damage to the muscle layer and thus it belongs to stage 4.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Stage 1: Non-blanchable erythema of intact skin. Redness that does not fade when pressure is applied.
  • Stage 2: Partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The wound bed is viable, pink or red, and moist.
  • Stage 3: Full-thickness skin loss. Subcutaneous fat may be visible, but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed.
  • Stage 4: Full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Exposed or directly palpable fascia, muscle, tendon, ligament, cartilage, or bone in the ulcer.
  • Unstageable: Obscured full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Extent of tissue damage within the ulcer cannot be confirmed because it is obscured by slough or eschar.
  • Deep Tissue Pressure Injury: Persistent non-blanchable deep red, maroon, or purple discoloration.

 

Treatment Focus:

 

  • Patient Optimization: Addressing poor nutrition and managing ongoing medical problems.
  • Preventative Measures: Implementing strategies to prevent further pressure injuries.
  • Debridement: Removing necrotic tissue if appropriate.

 

Given the extensive tissue destruction shown in the image, with damage extending through the muscle layer, the pressure sore is classified as a Stage 4 pressure injury.

choices.text: Malignant melanoma
Rosai Dorfman disease

questions.text: A woman who had undergone total knee replacement surgery comes with complaints of knee pain with the loosening of implants. The following histopathological slide was obtained which showed foreign body giant cells along with the appearance highlighted in the image below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metallosis

 

The given clinical scenario and image with the said foreign body giant cell point towards a diagnosis of metallosis.

 

Metallosis is an uncommon complication following total joint replacements of high wear joints like hip and knees. It occurs when metallic components in medical implants, specifically joint replacements, abrade against one another. The metal from the prosthesis infiltrates the bone and soft tissue surrounding it resulting in pain or squeaking on weight bearing or loosening of implant. Sometimes it may be asymptomatic with imaging findings (cloud sign or bubble sign). Aspiration reveals dark fluid consisting of metallic debris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ochronosis: Ochronosis is a metabolic disorder characterized by the deposition of homogentisic acid in connective tissues, leading to pigmentation and arthritis. It is not associated with metallic debris or foreign body giant cells.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: Malignant melanoma is a type of skin cancer that would present with different histological findings, such as atypical melanocytes. It does not involve foreign body giant cells or metallic debris.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman disease: This is a rare disorder characterized by massive lymphadenopathy and histiocytosis with distinctive histological features, including the presence of histiocytes that exhibit emperipolesis. It does not involve metallic particles or joint replacements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metallosis is a rare complication of joint replacement surgeries, characterized by the release of metallic debris from implants, leading to a foreign body reaction with the formation of foreign body giant cells and potential loosening of the implant.

choices.text: Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved
Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected

questions.text: What is correct regarding the diagnosis based on the given image?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

 

The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia (NOT Anterior nerve roots) for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • Thoracic dermatome is most commonly affected (NOT Trigeminal).
  • The rash is restricted to a dermatome, but sometimes a few chickenpox‐type lesions can be found elsewhere. The lesions are infectious
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved: False. In herpes zoster, it is the dorsal (posterior) nerve roots and ganglia that are predominantly involved, not the anterior nerve roots. The virus remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia and reactivates there, leading to symptoms in the corresponding dermatomal distribution.

 

Option C. The lesions are not infectious: False. The lesions of herpes zoster are highly infectious, particularly when the blisters are open and the fluid is accessible. The virus contained in these lesions can infect individuals who have not previously had chickenpox or the vaccine, leading to varicella (chickenpox).

 

Option D. Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected: False. While the trigeminal dermatome can be significantly affected (especially concerning due to the risk of herpes zoster ophthalmicus if the ophthalmic branch is involved), it is not the most commonly affected dermatome. The thoracic dermatomes are more frequently involved in herpes zoster cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster, commonly involves reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the dorsal root ganglion, leading to painful cutaneous eruptions that can affect mucous membranes within the involved dermatomes.
  • Herpes zoster lesions are infectious, particularly to those who are not immune to varicella-zoster virus, and thoracic dermatome is the most frequently affected area.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

choices.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
It is an obligate extracellular parasite
Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient shows the following features. Which of the following is true? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite

 

The given image shows the amastigote form of leishmaniasis located intracellularly in macrophages. Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite.

 

Buffy coat is the portion of blood that contains concentrates of white blood cells, including monocytes and platelets, and for obvious reasons its smear can be examined for detection of L. donovani bodies in suspected VL patients.

 

Detection of Leishmania donovani bodies in peripheral blood buffy coat smears is an alternative and minimally invasive procedure for the parasitological diagnosis of VL.

 

PCR assay with buffy coat preparations to detect Leishmania DNA has been found to be 10 times more sensitive than that with whole-blood preparation.

 

Serodiagnosis is a valid and the detection in serum and urine specimens of antileishmanial antibody against recombinant antigens such as rK39 by rapid immunochromatographic tests

 

Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.

 

Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test

 

Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is an obligate extracellular parasite: This is incorrect. Leishmania donovani is an intracellular parasite that resides within macrophages.

 

Option C. It is transmitted from sheep: This is incorrect. Leishmania is transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies, not by sheep.

 

Option D. Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India: This is partially outdated. Sodium stibogluconate was once the first line of treatment, but now liposomal amphotericin B and miltefosine are commonly used as first-line treatments in India due to increased resistance to antimonials.

 

Educational Objective:


Buffy coat is used to diagnose Leishmania donovani by detecting the amastigote form in intracellular macrophages in patients with visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text:
Arrange the structures of the cubital fossa in sequence from medial to lateral? (INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Median nerve

2. Radial nerve

3. Tendon of biceps brachi

4. Brachial artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,4,3,2

 

Explanation:

 

The structures are arranged in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral as follows:

 

1. Median nerve

2. Brachial artery

3. Tendon of biceps brachii

4. Radial nerve (Superficial Branch of radial nerve)

Mnemonic is MBBR
 

 

 

The cubital fossa is actually a triangular area located on the anterior aspect of the elbow, not the upper forearm. It is bounded by several structures, including:

 

  • The lateral border of the pronator teres muscle, which forms the medial boundary
  • The medial border of the brachioradialis muscle, which forms the lateral boundary
  • The imaginary line connecting the epicondyles of the humerus, which forms the superior boundary
  • The floor of the cubital fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles, while the roof is formed by the Deep fascia of the skin.
  • The roof of cubital fossa contains Subcutaneous veins which are used for routine phlebotomy procedures. These veins are - median cubital vein, cephalic vein and basilic vein

 

The cubital fossa contains several important structures, including the brachial artery, radial nerve, and median nerve. It is a common site for blood draws and intravenous catheter placement due to the relatively superficial location of the structures and ease of access.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct anatomical sequencing of structures in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral—median nerve, brachial artery, tendon of biceps brachii, and radial nerve—is essential for both anatomical education and practical clinical applications.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes. X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the diagnosis of this patient: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints;

B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthritis. In the involvement of spine & pelvis in psoriatic arthritis, the patient experiences extreme back/neck pain, stiffness in back/neck that improves on moving around. The stiffness worsens by a period of rest. There is difficulty in bending or moving the back. The patient also complaints of fatigue. The x-ray shows asymmetric paravertebral ossification, thicker & larger syndesmophytes than ankylosing spondylitis. Occasionally, there are incomplete non-marginal syndesmophytes similar to AS.

 

 

Option D. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. Etiology is genetic infection by paramyxovirus (measles and respiratory syncytial virus). There is increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Affects men > 50 years more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. The spine is the second most commonly affected site (53%), after the pelvis (70%). The lumbar spine and more commonly the L4 and L5 levels are the most frequently involved sites. Involvement of the atlanto-axial region is very rare. The vertebral body is almost always involved with a portion of the neural arch. The radiological appearance is characterised by an increase in the antero-posterior and lateral vertebral dimensions. The height of the vertebra is unchanged. The vertebral end-plates are subchondral condensations of trabecular bone and do not represent true bony cortex, i.e. there is no periosteum/endosteum interface at the caudal/cranial aspect of a normal vertebra. The “early” radiographic appearance of vertebral body is thickening and hypertrophy of the trabecular bone, parallel to the end plates. Progression of the sclerotic phase in the spine leads to “ivory vertebra”, due to an increase in the density of the vertebral body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes, along with the bamboo spine appearance in the spine x-ray are diagnostic of ankylosing spondylitis.

choices.text: 1 and 4 only

questions.text:
A skull was recovered from a forest. According to inquest papers, woman had gone missing after a fight with her boyfriend a month back. The skull was sent to the forensic research lab. Which of the following would identify it as a female skull? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. Large frontal and parietal eminence
  2. Heavy cheek bones
  3. Smooth glabella
  4. Square orbits
  5. Narrow mastoid
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 3 and 5   

 

Female Skull Characteristics:

 

1. Large frontal and parietal eminence: These are more prominent in females.

 

3. Smooth glabella: Females typically have a smoother glabella compared to males.

 

5. Narrow mastoid: Female mastoid processes are generally narrower and less prominent.

 

These characteristics help in identifying the skull as female.

 

Note - General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are

 

  • Size: Male bones are larger than female bones.
  • Roughness: Male bones are more rougher due to increased muscle attachment areas. Females have smooth features
  • Weight: Male bones are heavier than female bones
  • Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females.
  • Square features: Male have square features, whereas females have rounded features

 

So for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

 

Other Options

 

2. Heavy cheek bones: Typical in males, as a general rule, female bones are lighter than male bones.

 

4. Square orbits: Males have squarish features, whereas females have roundish features.

 

Educational objective

 

Most features are larger, rougher, and more prominent in male skull, except frontal eminence, parietal eminence and orbits which are more prominent or larger in females

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at the scene of a severe car accident. She is intubated on arrival due to poor airway protection and decreased consciousness. On examination, she opens her eyes only to painful stimuli and exhibits abnormal flexion in response to pain.
