Her pupils are reactive to light. The trauma team assesses her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score to monitor her neurological status. Based on her clinical findings, which of the following is her most appropriate GCS score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. E2VNTM3

 

Explanation:

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score evaluates eye, verbal, and motor responses to determine the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI). In this scenario, the patient scores 2 for eye opening to pain (E2), non-testable (NT) for verbal due to intubation, and 3 for abnormal flexion (M3). Thus, the GCS score is recorded as E2VNTM3. Non-testability (NT) denotes the inability to assess the verbal component due to intubation, often seen in acute TBI cases. The GCS-P score further refines this evaluation by considering pupillary activity, enhancing prognostic accuracy. While this patient’s GCS score focuses on eye and motor responses, her reactive pupils indicate no additional pupillary penalty in the GCS-P calculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E1VNTM2: This score implies no eye opening and abnormal extension (M2), which does not match the observed painful eye opening (E2) and abnormal flexion (M3).

 

Option B. E3VNTM2: This score incorrectly suggests eye opening to verbal command and abnormal extension posturing, which does not align with the patient's eye response to pain and abnormal flexion motor response.

 

Option C. E2VNTM4: This option overestimates the motor response as withdrawal from pain (M4), which inaccurately reflects the patient’s actual abnormal flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a widely used tool for assessing the level of consciousness in traumatic brain injury. Intubated patients are marked as non-testable (NT) for verbal response, focusing on eye and motor components. The GCS-P score further refines the assessment by incorporating pupillary activity, enhancing sensitivity and specificity in acute brain injury evaluation.

questions.text: The best way to manage the wound shown in the image is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cleaning and dressing

 

The image shows an abrasion. Since it is going to heal with primary intention, no grafting is required.

 

  • Cleaning the wound involves gently removing any debris, foreign material, or contaminants from the wound site. This step helps prevent infection and promotes a healthy healing environment.
  • Dressing the wound involves covering it with a sterile bandage or dressing. Dressings help maintain a moist environment, protect the wound from further contamination, and provide a barrier against external factors.

 

In many cases, initial wound management involves cleaning the wound to prevent infection and applying a sterile dressing. This basic approach is suitable for wounds that are not deeply contaminated, do not require extensive tissue removal (debridement), and do not necessitate advanced interventions like grafting (skin graft or allograft). It provides a clean and protected environment for natural healing to occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Debridement and dressing: Debridement involves the removal of dead or contaminated tissue from the wound, which may be necessary in cases of severe infection or tissue damage. After debridement, the wound is dressed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Here are some general principles for the management of a superficial abrasion:

 

  1. Clean the wound: Gently clean the wound with soap and warm water to remove any dirt or debris. Use a clean cloth or sterile gauze to pat the wound dry.
  2. Apply a dressing: Cover the abrasion with a sterile dressing or adhesive bandage to keep it clean and protected. Change the dressing daily or more often if it becomes wet or dirty.
  3. Manage pain: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  4. Watch for signs of infection: Keep an eye on the abrasion for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, pus, or increasing pain.
  5. Follow up: Depending on the severity of the abrasion, you may need to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment.

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 500-600 ml

 

Some of the water losses cannot be precisely regulated. For example, there is a continuous loss of water by evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin, which together account for about 500-600 ml/day of water loss under normal conditions. This is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When calculating the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient, it is essential to account for approximately 500-600 ml/day of insensible water loss due to evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

choices.text: Activated partial thromboplastin time
Prothrombin time

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with a big lesion on his forearm. As a surgery resident you decide to excise the lesion in the emergency operation theatre. Which of the following investigations will test the entire coagulation pathway? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thromboelastography

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) tests the entire coagulation pathway. It measures coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis.

 

It is a test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot. The advantages are:

 

  • Global assessment of blood coagulability, including coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis
  • Rapid real-time bedside test with a simple methodology (point-of-care testing)
  • Diagnosis of coagulopathic bleeding
  • Guide transfusion therapy and decrease the use of blood products
  • Detect dynamic changes in blood coagulation during resuscitation
  • Predict the clinical efficacy of therapeutic agents affecting blood coagulability

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT): aPTT assesses the intrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade. It does not measure platelet function or fibrinolysis, so it does not test the entire coagulation pathway.

 

Option B. Prothrombin time (PT): PT assesses the extrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade. Similar to aPTT, it does not evaluate platelet function or fibrinolysis, making it less comprehensive than TEG.

 

Option D. Bleeding time: Bleeding time is primarily a test of platelet function and vascular integrity. It does not assess the coagulation cascade or fibrinolysis and thus does not provide a full picture of the coagulation pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) is the most comprehensive test for evaluating the entire coagulation pathway, including coagulation factor activity, platelet function, and fibrinolysis, making it ideal for intraoperative and emergency settings.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537061/

questions.text: The graph below shows the relationship between the log(dose) and the response of three drugs, A, B, and C. Which of these drugs has the highest potency? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

  • The potency of a drug corresponds to the power of the drug. The drug which produces the response at a lower dose is more potent than another drug which produces the same response at a higher dose.
  • The more left the curve is on the DRC, the greater is its potency.
  • On the other hand, efficacy means the maximum response that is produced by a drug. In a DRC, the more the height of the curve, the more efficacious that drug is.

 

Therefore in this case,

 

  • The potency of Drug A > Drug B > Drug C
  • The Efficacy of Drug A = Drug B > Drug C

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a dose-response curve, the drug with the curve furthest to the left is the most potent because it produces the desired effect at the lowest dose. In this case, Drug A is the most potent.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metoclopramide

 

Metoclopramide is an anti-emetic that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can cross the blood brain barrier and can lead to Dopaminergic blockade in the various parts of the brain leading to Acute dystonia, drowsiness, abnormal posturing, Parkinsonism etc.

 

Domperidone is also a D2 Receptor blocker, but cannot cross the BBB, therefore it does not produce such side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that does not typically cause extrapyramidal side effects. It is used to reduce salivation and bronchial secretions and to treat bradycardia.

 

Option B. Ranitidine: Ranitidine is an H2 receptor antagonist used to reduce stomach acid production. It does not have significant central nervous system effects or cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Domperidone: Domperidone is also a dopamine D2 receptor blocker used as an anti-emetic. However, it does not cross the blood-brain barrier effectively and therefore does not typically cause central nervous system side effects like metoclopramide.

 

Educational Objective

 

Metoclopramide, an anti-emetic that blocks D2 receptors and crosses the blood-brain barrier, can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as acute dystonia, drowsiness, abnormal posturing, and Parkinsonism-like symptoms.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old individual arrives with painless rectal bleeding. Which of the listed investigations are conducted for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Colonoscopy
  2. CECT
  3. CEA
  4. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

 

1. Colonoscopy: This is an endoscopic examination of the large bowel and the distal part of the small bowel. It provides a visual diagnosis and can offer biopsy or removal of suspected lesions. It is an essential diagnostic tool for any patient with per-rectal bleeding to identify potential sources such as polyps, tumors, or colitis.

 

2. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):  CECT can provide detailed cross-sectional images of the body. In the context of rectal bleeding, it might be used to evaluate the extent of a detected tumor, check for metastatic disease, or to view vascular anomalies that might be causing the bleeding, such as arteriovenous malformations.

 

3. CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen): CEA is a tumor marker. Its level can be elevated in colorectal cancers as well as other malignancies and conditions. Monitoring the levels of CEA might help in diagnosing, prognosis, and checking the recurrence of colorectal cancers. 

 

Other Option:

 

4. CA 19-9: CA 19-9 is another tumor marker. It is more typically associated with pancreatic cancer. However, its specificity for colorectal cancer is not as high as CEA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the patient's presenting symptom of painless rectal bleeding:

 

  • Colonoscopy is a primary diagnostic tool to visualize and biopsy any potential sources of bleeding.
  • CECT could be useful in determining the extent of a potential tumor or to check for other causes of bleeding.
  • CEA might be used to check for the possibility of colorectal cancer.

 

Hence, the investigations that would be most appropriate and relevant for this patient would be options 1, 2, and 3. Therefore, answer choice D) 1, 2, and 3 is correct.

choices.text: Spurious drug
Adulterated drug
Unethical drug
Misbranded drug

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

 

A misbranded drug refers to a drug whose labeling is inaccurate or misleading. This includes incorrect labeling of the quantity of active ingredients. In this scenario, where the medication is labeled as containing 500 mg of paracetamol but actually contains only 200 mg, it would be considered a misbranded drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious drugs: These products are manufactured concealing the true identity of the product and made to resemble another drug, especially some popular brand, to deceive the buyer and cash on the popularity of original product. The product may or may not contain the active ingredients. Spurious drugs are usually manufactured by unlicensed anti-social elements but sometimes licensed manufacturers may also be involved.

 

Option B. Adulterated drugs: These are those drugs which are found to contain an adulterant/substituted product or contaminated with filth rendering it injurious to health

 

Option C. Unethical drug: "Unethical drug" is not a standard term in pharmaceutical regulation. The issue here is not primarily about ethics but rather about the accuracy of labeling and drug quality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A drug labeled inaccurately with respect to its active ingredient quantity is considered a misbranded drug. Ensuring accurate labeling is crucial for regulatory compliance and consumer safety, as it ensures that drugs on the market are labeled truthfully and can be trusted for their intended use.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents to the obstetrics clinic for routine prenatal care. She has a known history of Graves' disease and was started on antithyroid medication before conception. She reports compliance with her medication but is concerned about potential effects on her baby. Physical examination is unremarkable, and her thyroid function tests show slightly elevated free T4 and suppressed TSH. The patient continues her pregnancy without complications until delivery at term. At birth, the newborn is noted to have a congenital scalp defect, characterized as aplasia cutis congenita. Given the history and clinical findings, which antithyroid drug used during pregnancy is most likely responsible for this congenital abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Carbimazole

 

Explanation:

 

Carbimazole is an antithyroid drug that is metabolized into Methimazole (MMI) in the body. Both Carbimazole and Methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects, particularly when used during the first trimester of pregnancy, due to their impact on fetal development during organogenesis. These drugs can cause congenital anomalies, including aplasia cutis congenita, a condition characterized by localized absence of skin, commonly on the scalp. To minimize these risks, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is recommended during the first trimester as it has a lower teratogenic profile. After 16 weeks of gestation, the treatment typically switches to Methimazole or Carbimazole because PTU is associated with hepatotoxicity, which is more concerning later in pregnancy. During lactation, Methimazole is preferred, and Radioactive Iodine is avoided, particularly in the early postpartum period, to prevent radiation exposure to the infant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propylthiouracil (PTU)
PTU is preferred during the first trimester of pregnancy due to its lower risk of teratogenicity compared to Carbimazole and Methimazole. Although it can cause hepatotoxicity, it does not lead to aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Option C. Lugol's Iodine
Lugol's Iodine is sometimes used to reduce thyroid hormone levels rapidly but is not commonly associated with congenital defects like aplasia cutis congenita. Its primary use is in preparation for thyroid surgery or severe hyperthyroidism, and it is not considered a first-line antithyroid drug during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Radioactive Iodine (RAI)
Radioactive Iodine is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its destructive effects on fetal thyroid tissue. However, it is not linked to aplasia cutis congenita and is strictly avoided during pregnancy and lactation to prevent harm to the fetus and infant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbimazole and Methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects, especially when used in the first trimester, including the risk of aplasia cutis congenita. To minimize fetal risks, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred during early pregnancy, with a switch to Methimazole or Carbimazole after the first trimester due to PTU’s potential hepatotoxicity. During lactation, Methimazole is preferred, and Radioactive Iodine is strictly avoided to protect the infant from radiation exposure through breast milk

questions.text: Which vaccine is not recommended to be given before splenectomy in a 5-year-old child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Typhoid vaccine

 

The typhoid vaccine is typically not recommended before splenectomy in a child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism. Typhoid vaccination may lead to a transient decrease in platelet count, which can exacerbate the existing hypersplenism and increase the risk of bleeding. Therefore, it is often deferred until after splenectomy when the risk of post-vaccination thrombocytopenia is reduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal vaccine: The pneumococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia (absence of the spleen) or hyposplenism (reduced spleen function) because they are at an increased risk of severe infections, including those caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the pneumococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenza B vaccine: The Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccine is recommended as part of routine childhood immunization and does not have specific contraindications related to hereditary spherocytosis or splenectomy.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: The meningococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia or hyposplenism, as they are at an increased risk of meningococcal infections. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the meningococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typhoid vaccine is often deferred in children with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism before splenectomy due to the risk of transiently reduced platelet count, which can be problematic in the presence of hypersplenism. Other vaccines, such as the pneumococcal, Haemophilus influenzae B, and meningococcal vaccines, may be administered based on routine immunization recommendations and the individual's spleen status.

choices.text: Bipolar disorder

questions.text: Which of the following is not an off-label use of risperidone? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bipolar disorder
 

Off-label drug use refers to the prescription of a medication for a condition that is not included in its approved labeling by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

 

Risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is specifically approved for the short-term treatment of acute manic or mixed episodes associated with Bipolar I Disorder, both as monotherapy and as an adjunct to lithium or valproate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder): The use of risperidone for OCD is generally considered off-label. While antipsychotics like risperidone can be used adjunctively in treatment-resistant OCD, it's not an FDA-approved indication.

 

Option B. Dementia: Using risperidone for the treatment of behavioral symptoms in dementia is off-label. Although it's sometimes prescribed for this purpose, it's important to note that the FDA has issued a black box warning about the increased risk of death when using antipsychotic drugs in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis.

 

Option C. PTSD: (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder): The use of risperidone in PTSD is also off-label. It has been studied and used for managing certain symptoms of PTSD, but it is not an FDA-approved indication for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of bipolar disorder, making it a labeled use. In contrast, the use of risperidone for OCD, dementia, and PTSD are off-label indications.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liposarcoma

 

Liposarcoma is the most commonly observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space. Liposarcomas are malignant tumors that arise from adipocytes and are most frequently located in the retroperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of muscle origin. While it can occur in various parts of the body, it is more commonly associated with pediatric populations in the neck.

 

Option C. Synovial sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that tends to arise near large joints but can occur anywhere in the body.

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors. While they can occur in various parts of the body, including the retroperitoneum, they are not the most frequently observed tumor in this location. It's also important to note that when associated with certain genetic conditions like Neurofibromatosis type 1, they can be seen in multiple areas of the body, but they still don't surpass liposarcomas in frequency in the retroperitoneal space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins.
  • Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors.
  • The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors.
  • Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma.
  • Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.text: The rise in blood pressure that occurs at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is a result of? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

 

Valsalva maneuver can lead to a temporary increase in blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system. This phenomenon can be explained by:

 

  • Increased Intrathoracic Pressure: By trying to exhale against a closed airway, you create increased pressure within your chest cavity. This can compress the large blood vessels.
  • Increased Sympathetic Activity: The increased intrathoracic pressure triggers the body’s sympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the “fight or flight” response. This leads to the release of stress hormones like adrenaline and norepinephrine. These hormones cause blood vessels to constrict (vasoconstriction), which further raises blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure: Incorrect. The pressure increase primarily affects the aorta and systemic circulation, not just the left ventricular pressure.

 

Option C. Increase in left atrial pressure: Incorrect. While there may be a slight increase in left atrial pressure, it is not the primary cause of the rise in blood pressure observed during the Valsalva maneuver.

 

Option D. Increase in left ventricular volume: Incorrect. The maneuver does not directly increase left ventricular volume; instead, it increases pressure within the thoracic cavity affecting the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

The rise in blood pressure at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is primarily due to the increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure, along with increased sympathetic activity.

choices.text: Platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 (PECAM-1)

questions.text: Which of the following molecules are involved in helping the leukocytes to roll over the endothelial cells in the vessels? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E-selectin

 

E-selectins are involved in rolling of leucocytes over endothelial cells.

 

Cellular Changes during Inflammation

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cadherins: These are involved in cell-cell adhesion in various tissues but are not specifically involved in the rolling of leukocytes during inflammation.

 

Option B. PECAM-1 (Platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1): PECAM-1 is primarily involved in the process of diapedesis, where leukocytes transmigrate across the endothelium.

 

Option D. CD11a: This is an integrin (part of the LFA-1 complex) involved in the firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium, not in the rolling process.

 

Educational Objective:


E-selectin is critical for the rolling of leukocytes along the endothelial cells during the early stages of the inflammatory response.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man with a recent diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) has been undergoing treatment with arsenic trioxide and all-trans retinoic acid. After one week of therapy, he presents to the emergency department with high fever, shortness of breath, and new bilateral infiltrates on his chest X-ray. His physical examination reveals tachypnea and mild hypoxia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dexamethasone

 

Explanation:

 

This patient’s presentation is highly suggestive of differentiation syndrome, a serious complication associated with the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) with arsenic trioxide and all-trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by fever, respiratory distress, pulmonary infiltrates, and pleural effusions that develop during the initial weeks of therapy. The first-line treatment is high-dose corticosteroids, specifically dexamethasone, which helps reduce inflammation and prevent progression of the syndrome. Prompt recognition and early administration of dexamethasone can significantly improve outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Ciprofloxacin: While ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic used for bacterial infections, it is not effective in treating differentiation syndrome. This syndrome is inflammatory rather than infectious, so antibiotics are not beneficial unless a secondary bacterial infection is confirmed.

 

Option C) Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication typically used for invasive fungal infections. Although immunocompromised patients like those with leukemia may be at risk for fungal infections, the clinical features of differentiation syndrome do not align with those of a fungal etiology.

 

Option D) Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): IVIG is used in various conditions, including autoimmune disorders and certain immunodeficiencies. However, it has no role in managing differentiation syndrome, which primarily requires anti-inflammatory therapy rather than immune modulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differentiation syndrome is a potentially life-threatening complication of acute promyelocytic leukemia treatment with arsenic trioxide and all-trans retinoic acid. It presents with fever, respiratory distress, and pulmonary infiltrates, and is effectively treated with high-dose corticosteroids like dexamethasone. Prompt recognition and initiation of corticosteroids are essential for reducing morbidity and preventing progression.

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+

 

ER+ is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients as it is seen with luminal A and B subtypes of the breast cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High Ki67+: High Ki67+ indicates a high proliferative index, which is associated with more aggressive tumors and a poorer prognosis.

 

Option C. BRCA1+: BRCA1 mutation is associated with an increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers, and these cancers tend to be more aggressive.

 

Option D. P53+: P53 mutations are associated with a variety of cancers and typically indicate a poorer prognosis due to the loss of normal p53 tumor suppressor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER-positive status in breast cancer is a good prognostic factor because it indicates a slower-growing tumor that is likely to respond well to hormone therapy.

 

Why ER⁺ is a Good Prognostic Factor:

 

  1. Slower tumor growth:
    • ER⁺ tumors tend to grow more slowly than ER⁻ tumors.
  2. Better treatment response:
    • ER⁺ cancers respond well to hormonal therapies such as:
    • Tamoxifen
    • Aromatase inhibitors
  3. Lower recurrence risk:
    • Hormone receptor–positive cancers have a lower risk of early recurrence.
  4. Overall survival:
    • Patients with ER⁺ tumors generally have better overall survival.

choices.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava
Right and left lobe of liver

questions.text: The cholecysto-vena caval line is an anatomical landmark that connects which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gallbladder and inferior vena cava

 

  • The cholecysto-vena caval line (Cantlie line) considered as true mid line of liver.
  • The Cantlie line is a fictitious line that divides the liver into two parts.
  • It contains the middle hepatic vein and extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the groove for inferior vena cava (IC).

 

 

Anatomy on visceral surface of the liver with division into right and left lobes by the plane of Rex-Cantlie line.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Porta Hepatis and Inferior Vena Cava: The porta hepatis, often called the "hilum of the liver," is a deep fissure on the inferior surface of the liver where several key structures, including the portal vein, common hepatic duct, and hepatic artery, enter or leave the liver. Though the porta hepatis is an essential landmark in liver anatomy and surgery, it's not associated with the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option C. Caudate Lobe and Quadrangular Lobe: There isn't a distinct "quadrangular lobe" in the human liver. The liver has main lobes named right, left, caudate, and quadrate lobes. The caudate and quadrate lobes are smaller lobes situated on the liver's inferior surface. While they have importance in liver anatomy, they don't define the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option D. Right and Left Lobe of Liver: On the Diaphragamatic surface Tthe human liver is typically divided into a larger right lobe and a smaller left lobe by the falciform ligament (anteriorly). The cholecysto-vena caval line helps delineate the boundary between the right and left lobes when viewed posteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholecysto-vena caval line is an imaginary line drawn from the fundus of the gallbladder to the point where the inferior vena cava (IVC) pierces the diaphragm. It roughly demarcates the boundary between the right and left lobes of the liver, especially when viewed from behind (posterior view).

choices.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length pair technique
RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following is more appropriate for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genome?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

 

RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

 

To quantitatively analyze viral RNA genomes, two key processes are required:

 

  1. Reverse Transcription (RT): Viral RNA must first be converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) can only amplify DNA. This is done using Reverse Transcriptase, hence RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR).
  2. Quantification using Real Time PCR (qPCR): Once the cDNA is synthesized, Real-Time PCR is used to quantify the amount of target nucleic acid in real time using fluorescent markers.

 

 

Thus, for quantitative analysis of viral RNA:
 

  • First step → RT-PCR
  • Second step → Real-Time PCR (qPCR)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Real Time PCR: This refers to quantification but only works with DNA, not directly with RNA. Without the reverse transcription step, it cannot quantify viral RNA.
 

Option B. Conventional PCR with RFLP: This is qualitative and used for genotyping or mutation detection, not quantitative analysis.
 

Option C. RT-PCR: RT-PCR alone allows detection of RNA (qualitative), but not quantification unless combined with Real-Time PCR.

 

Educational Objective:


RT PCR followed by Real-time PCR is the most appropriate technique for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, allowing real-time monitoring and quantification of viral RNA load.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen causing injury. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Caudate lobe of liver

 

Explanation:

 

The caudate lobe is a small, distinct lobe of the liver that lies posterior to the porta hepatis and forms the posterior border of the lesser omentum. Importantly, it forms the superior border of the epiploic foramen. Thus, during cholecystectomy, an injury advancing the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen could damage the caudate lobe.

 

Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac.

 

 

Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of bleeding from the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right lobe of liver: The right lobe of the liver is a major lobe, and it constitutes the majority of the liver's mass. It does not directly border the epiploic foramen. The anterior surface of the right lobe faces the anterior abdominal wall, and the posterior surface is related to the diaphragm and right kidney.

 

Option B. Quadrate lobe of liver: The quadrate lobe is a smaller lobe situated on the visceral surface of the liver. It is bounded by the gallbladder on the right and the round ligament of the liver on the left. It is separated from the left lobe by the fissure for the ligamentum teres. While it's close to the region, the quadrate lobe does not form the superior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Option D. Fundus of gallbladder: The fundus is the most distal part of the gallbladder and it usually projects beyond the inferior border of the liver, contacting the anterior abdominal wall. It is not directly related to the epiploic foramen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boundaries of epiploic foramen
